choices.E: Show column profile in details pane

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Fabric tenant that contains a dataflow.

You are exploring a new semantic model.

From Power Query, you need to view column information as shown in the following exhibit.

//IMG//


Which three Data view options should you select? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.

discussion.content:
C Enable column profile
A Show column value distribution
D Show Column quality details

Selected Answer: AD
As per the screenshot, there are only 2 options to show that information: 1st is "Column Distribution" and 2nd is "Column Quality". I don't know why it is asking for 3 and when we select "Column profile" it shows statistics and value distribution.

comments.content: In PowerQuery in Dataflow 'Enable column profile' is there and it has to be selected to show other view options. However, PowerQuery in PowerBI does not have this option 'Enable column profile'.
I agree, column profile is not necesary to show the info in pictures. But question request 3 option, so we have to add it
Column Profile is one more checkbox you overlooked

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
it was in the exam 27.03.25

Selected Answer: ACD
simply there is no pane here, everything is showed in the upper box

Selected Answer: ACD
Show column value distribution: This option provides a visual representation of the distribution of values in each column, which is visible in the exhibit.

Enable column profile: This option displays statistics and other detailed information about each column, including value distribution, which aligns with the data shown in the exhibit.

Show column quality details: This option shows the quality of the data in each column, indicating valid, error, and empty values, as displayed in the exhibit.

Selected Answer: ACD
IMHO, ACD is good.

There is no example for details, so B and E are not needed

Selected Answer: ACD
ACD for sure. Tested
ACD for sure

Selected Answer: ACD
Tested it with a dataflow in Fabric

Selected Answer: ACD
A: Show column value 
C: Enable column profile
D: Show Column quality

comments.content: Sorry misleading it is C A D as taphyoe said

discussion.content: Hm.Just tested this. I suggest this answers: C – enable column profile, E – Show column quality details, A-Show Column Value distribution. Dette er testet
GREATEST, COALESCE

Correct Answer 
GREATEST, COALESCE

SELECT 
 ProductID,
 GREATEST(ListPrice, WholesalePrice, AgentPrice) AS HighestSellingPrice,
 COALESCE(AgentPrice, WholesalePrice, ListPrice) AS TradePrice
FROM 
 Sales.Products;
I believe that the 2nd box should be COALESCE, but if you read requirements for TradePrice column, you will realize that actually, COALESCE will not work here. Clearly there's a mistake somewhere.

comments.content: yeah, the list is inverted, and so is the logic
Yes, it seems like there is no correct answer for the second box

discussion.content: Greatest is ok; however, if we have all of them present, list price will return first if you use coalesce, which is not what the question requests. The question requests AgentPrice first. I am not sure about Coalesce.
answer is correct

MAX
COALESCE

comments.content: MAX() accepts one argument; GREATEST() accepts multiple arguments

IMHO, datetrunc & weekday

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/functions/datetrunc-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver16

Just echecked it. Date trunc returns the first date of the month and datepart just the month number. So given answer is correct.
Note: The weekday, timezoneoffset, and nanosecond T-SQL dateparts aren't supported for DATETRUNC. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/functions/datetrunc-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver16

The DATETRUNC function returns an input date truncated to a specified datepart.
